topics.body: Silly question, I know you can use an Intel Xeon instead of the desktop versions of their CPU's for a desktop, but does it strike anyone as weird? I mean I'm using it for something it's not really meant for; I feel like everything I do on it is...industrialized, if that even makes sense. It's like buying a commercial truck just to drive to the grocery store or a commercial fishing boat to tow a water-skier. I just feel strange using something like that for personal use. Also the mobo and RAM would be server-grade as well which only makes me feel more uncomfortable.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5377b52c63687271b1160400#post_5377b52c63687271b1160400
But think of how well you could play games on it.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5377b65e6368726ed0680400#post_5377b65e6368726ed0680400
As far as I know the performance is the same as the Core series; the speeds, the cache levels, the memory channels and speeds..., everything is the same, even the price is almost the same. The only reason I want a Xeon is because they are better, they are the cream of the crop so to speak which is why there are selected for servers and workstations that will be on 24/7 and under heavy use all the time and they support ECC also.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
